items.title: Plans to burn red tingle trees temporarily suspended following treetop protest
items.summary: The WA government abandons plans to burn a parcel of forest that is home to a species of rare tree after a 70-year-old man spent six nights living in the canopy.

items.title: Bonnie Deas putting WNBL lessons to use in US college basketball with University of Arkansas
items.summary: Bonnie Deas is shining in US college basketball, and she puts a lot of her success down to a WNBL semifinal trial by fire against Australian basketball great Sami Whitcomb.

items.title: Donald Trump sparks Denmark's anger by appointing US envoy to Greenland
items.summary: US President Donald Trump appoints a special envoy to Greenland, drawing renewed criticism from Denmark and the territory's leader over Washington's interest in the mineral-rich Arctic island.

items.title: In a 'complete 180', graziers get early Christmas present with significant rainfall
items.summary: The heavy rainfall is welcomed by graziers and follows months of dry conditions in the state's far-west, with hot temperatures and wind battering the land.

items.title: Thunderstorm arrives in Broken Hill ahead of Christmas.
items.summary: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

items.title: Poor sleep, unhealthy diets and stress compound to leave homeless at risk of dying decades early
items.summary: Western Australian research is showing a strong link between homelessness and poor health, with life expectancy more than 30 years lower for people without secure housing.

items.title: WA's water regulator is probing South32's impacts on neighbouring farmland
items.summary: The owner of a farm neighbouring South32's major bauxite mine in WA claims the miner is responsible for rising salinity and reduced water availability at his property. His claims are now being probed by WA's regulator.

items.title: The making of Handel's Messiah into a centuries-old Christmas classic
items.summary: Composed in just three weeks, Handel’s Messiah remains a beloved classic nearly 300 years on. Its origin story is marked by scandal and links to slavery.

items.title: Caravans left unattended at free riverside campsite spark debate over fair access
items.summary: Unattended caravans line a popular Murray River campsite, triggering debate over whether public camping spots are being quietly claimed ahead of the busy holiday season.

items.title: Concerns of a rise in "ghost camping" along the Murray River.
items.summary: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

items.title: Cross-border commissioner's death leaves border towns in limbo
items.summary: Towns, like Goondiwindi on the Queensland-New South Wales border, wait to see who will replace the late Ian Leavers in the role of cross-border commissioner and continue his work.

items.title: Victorian State Electricity Commission new owner of Delburn wind farm in Gippsland
items.summary: The Victorian government says the wind farm's 33 turbines will generate enough electricity to power more than 130,000 homes.

items.title: What are you really paying when using a card this Christmas?
items.summary: Cashless payments make up about three-quarters of all transactions in Australia but come at a cost to both merchants and consumers, leaving some asking if it is time to consider it essential infrastructure.

items.title: Live markets updates: ASX set to open slightly up while gold prices hit fresh record
items.summary: The Australian share market looks set to open slightly up while the price of gold jumps to a fresh record. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: The Epstein files divided Trump's base and now more fights are brewing
items.summary: The release of the Epstein files followed some of Donald Trump's dedicated supporters launching a rare revolt against the US president. Here are six more issues that could also divide Republicans.

items.title: New early detection cameras in NSW spotting fires before they spread
items.summary: New cameras using AI have been installed in southern New South Wales forests and are spotting fires before they have a chance to spread.

items.title: Wild Christmas week ahead for Queensland with days of severe storms forecast as temperatures ease
items.summary: The weather bureau is forecasting heavy rainfall and thunderstorms for large parts of the state over the Christmas week, but temperatures are expected to ease.

items.title: Swiss court to hear Pari islanders' climate change case against cement giant Holcim
items.summary: Residents of the tiny Indonesian island of Pari, which risks being swallowed by rising seas, win the right to have their climate change case against cement giant Holcim heard in a Swiss court.

items.title: Two men die in separate stabbing incidents in Melbourne on Monday
items.summary: A man died after he was stabbed during an altercation in Clyde, in Melbourne's south-east. Just hours later another man was fatally stabbed in Fitzroy.

items.title: Russian general Fanil Sarvarov killed by car bomb in Moscow, officials say
items.summary: The Kremlin is probing who is behind the killing, which has similarities to previous attacks by Ukrainian special services.

items.title: Domestic violence survivor calls for national register to stop perpetrators 'exploiting' loopholes
items.summary: Advocates are pushing for a national framework for addressing domestic violence after an ABC investigation highlighted gaps in the justice system and a lack of information sharing between states.

items.title: Thousands of birds are dying on a remote island with no end in sight
items.summary: The Isle of May is the epicentre of a deadly outbreak of the H5N1 bird flu strain which has spread throughout the globe. Scientists are warning Australia could be next.

items.title: Driving Home for Christmas singer Chris Rea dies aged 74
items.summary: The man best known for his festive hit Driving Home for Christmas died surrounded by his family.

items.title: Sisters in Sweat — the Sunday football session that grew a sporting movement of over 15,000 Indian women
items.summary: Eight years ago, Swetha Subbiah was asked to run a single football session for a friend. She ended up starting a sporting movement, which now has 15,000 women and girls as members across Bengaluru, Mumbai, Hyderabad and Delhi.

items.title: Liberal-linked Tasmanian public relations firm Font PR shuts
items.summary: It has helped keep the Liberals in power in Tasmania and lobbied on behalf of Airbnb, the salmon industry and the Catholic Church — but the PR firm, described as having "fingers in a lot of pies", is closing down.

items.title: A chaotic 'up-crash' as markets and economic realities made for a turbulent 2025
items.summary: AI. Market records. Tariffs. Penguins. TACO. It's been a big year of economic shocks and surges as the international framework of global trade was shredded. Here's how key players saw the year that was.

items.title: World's largest warship looms near Venezuela as US warns of land attacks
items.summary: The Pentagon moved the USS Gerald R Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, to the Caribbean last month. Now, President Donald Trump is repeating threats of imminent strikes against Venezuelan territory.

items.title: The Christmas display at West Hindmarsh delighting children, adults and nuns
items.summary: Families from all over Adelaide visit Joe Ferraro's home to marvel at his Christmas display, which he has amassed a collection of more than 50,000 lights since he began nearly 20 years ago.

items.title: Beekepers on high alert as bee-killing varroa mite spreads in South Australia
items.summary: The varroa mite may be tiny — only a millimetre or two long — but it poses a huge threat to honey bees, beekeepers and honey producers, who are on high alert after the destructive mite's recent arrival in South Australia.

items.title: Under-16s social media ban sees rise in alternatives in app store
items.summary: The Commonwealth's long-awaited social media ban for under-16s came into effect this month. But some experts note a rise in alternatives to popular platforms as teens find ways to stay active on social media.

items.title: Videos and CCTV give fresh insight into gunmen's plot to target Bondi Beach
items.summary: Security camera footage captured the Bondi Beach gunmen carrying what appears to be firearms out of a south-west Sydney property on the morning of the terror attack, court documents reveal.

items.title: Better late than never: The gas fix to a problem that should never have been
items.summary: The gas export industry has cost the nation dearly. East coast prices trebled soon after exports began.

items.title: Steven Cubis was the face of GIM Trading when investors lost millions but his story began long before then
items.summary: Steven Cubis hides behind a charming facade, but his former lover and friends say the career con man ruined them financially and emotionally long before he was caught up in allegations of a multi-million-dollar fraud.

items.title: Today in History, December 23: Uruguay legalises recreational cannabis use
items.summary: Twelve years ago today, Uruguay became the first country to legalise recreational marijuana use. The experiment is still unfolding.

items.title: Unhinged Christmas movies quiz: Can you pick the real movies from these ridiculous plots?
items.summary: Once December rolls around, there's nothing the minor movie studios love more than getting their most unhinged Christmas tropes out of cold storage.

items.title: Fire Rescue Victoria sues United Firefighters Union over $1.6m in taxpayer-funded 'service fees'
items.summary: Taxpayers have funded $1.6 million in payments to the firefighters union via Fire Rescue Victoria, court documents allege, under an income protection scheme the state's fire chief has said should outrage all Victorians.

items.title: Man behind deadly Taiwan metro attack planned it for over a year
items.summary: Police in Taiwan say Chang Wen purchased grenades, gas canisters and respirators in the year leading up to Friday's attack.

items.title: Uber and Lyft partner with Chinese tech giant for self-driving cars in London
items.summary: Rideshare companies Uber and Lyft are planning to bring self-driving cars to the streets of London in the first half of 2026.

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia set to resume ceasefire negotiations amid deadly border conflict
items.summary: Bangkok says the two countries will return to the negotiating table this week amid claims the initial peace deal was rushed for Donald Trump.

items.title: Kyrgios not offered Australian Open wildcard as four other Aussies named
items.summary: After a career-best year, Queenslander Priscilla Hon was among four Australian Open wildcards named on Monday, but Nick Kyrgios was not among them.

items.title: Glenelg beachside retail precinct reopens after tumultuous period for businesses
items.summary: Traders along one of Adelaide's most popular beachside dining and retail strips have welcomed the reopening of roads to traffic, but say recovery will take time.

items.title: Festive season to bring Christmas Day heatwave to Perth and Cocos Island tropical cyclone
items.summary: Perth is expected to hit a high of 41 degrees on Christmas Day with the Cocos (Keeling) Islands bracing for a tropical cyclone that could intensify to a category two system.

items.title: Japan prepares to restart world's biggest nuclear plant, 15 years after Fukushima
items.summary: Japan has taken the final step to allow the world's largest nuclear power plant to resume operations with a regional vote in Niigata prefecture.

items.title: City Beach fined $14m by Federal Court over button battery safety breaches
items.summary: The Federal Court orders the fashion retailer to pay $14 million in fines after it was taken to court by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

items.title: Racing tribunal bans greyhound trainer Gerry Orr for six years over prohibited substances
items.summary: Victorian trainer Gerry Orr has received a six-year ban for procuring performance-enhancing drugs after he inadvertently alerted stewards by giving authorities his mobile phone.

items.title: Queensland man arrested following dozens of antisemitic graffiti offences
items.summary: A Coolum Beach man is charged with 25 counts of wilful damage following a spate of antisemitic graffiti incidents.

items.title: Should I pour leftover liquids or foods down the sink?
items.summary: Ever been about to pour rancid milk down the sink and thought, "Hmm, maybe I shouldn't…"? What about the tomato passata that's gone off? Or the water you washed the paint in? Or that pungent oil from a tuna can?

items.title: Prince William and Prince George help make Christmas lunch at homelessness charity in London

items.title: Family tells inquest young mother 'died of a broken heart' as system failed to protect her

items.title: Stuart Broad still believes Australia's Ashes-winning team is their worst side in 15 years
items.summary: Stuart Broad has attracted plenty of criticism for his low opinion of the current Australian team but the England great stands by his harsh assessment.

items.title: Anthony Albanese apologises for what Jewish community experienced after Bondi attack
items.summary: Anthony Albanese says he is "sorry" for what Jewish Australians have experienced, while announcing a package of legislative changes.

items.title: Pittsburgh Steelers star DK Metcalf lashes out at Detroit Lions fan
items.summary: Steelers wide receiver DK Metcalf is expected to face scrutiny after he attempted to strike a fan in the second quarter of Pittsburgh's win over Detroit.

items.title: Industry and musicians explore ways to make vinyl records more environmentally friendly
items.summary: Artists like Stella Donnelly are searching for ways to cut waste and make production of their albums environmentally friendly.

items.title: Why Mitchell Starc is open to playing on to the 2027 Ashes series
items.summary: Mitchell Starc will be 37 by the time the 2027 Ashes kicks off in 18 months' time, but the in-form quick is open to spearheading Australia's attack in their next clash with England.

items.title: Children and staff abducted from Nigerian school released
items.summary: No group has claimed responsibility for the November 21 abduction of more than 300 children and staff from a Nigerian Catholic school.

items.title: Building a village means showing up even when it feels hard, says Esther Perel
items.summary: Building and maintaining a village doesn't just happen. It takes effort. It means showing up even when it feels hard or inconvenient, says psychotherapist Esther Perel.

items.title: Lake George hides an earthquake fault zone, and scientists are using your road noise to see it

items.summary: Calls for the federal government to hold a royal commission into the Bondi terror attack continue after NSW announced intentions for a state-level royal commission, prompting some confusion about the difference.

items.title: Seasonal workers claim unfair bonus cuts and poor conditions on NSW cherry orchard
items.summary: Ten pickers who worked at Hallmark Cherries' orchard in NSW complain about poorly maintained accommodation and failure to pay an end-of-season bonus.

items.title: How your town can become a 'dementia-friendly' community
items.summary: The small Victorian town of Ouyen, 440 kilometres north-west of Melbourne, is known for its grain and sheep farms, but also for being "dementia friendly".

items.summary: Transitioning from "the happiest nation on earth" to a fast-paced Western society is not without its challenges for Perth's booming Bhutanese population, some of whom have taken up archery to improve their mental health.

items.summary: Nathan Lyon's injury leaves selectors with another headache, made trickier by Pat Cummins's admission that he will almost certainly miss the Boxing Day Test now that the Ashes are won.

items.summary: A tropical low will bring heavy rain and storms to much of Queensland this week while a south-east heatwave persists.

items.title: Federal government announces 2027 gas reservation scheme, ASX rallies — as it happened
items.summary: The federal government announced its intention to start a gas reservation scheme from 2027. The ASX made a strong start to the shortened trading week.

items.title: Safety fears as Embark Education launches takeover bid for childcare rival, Mayfield
items.summary: Embark Education launches a takeover bid for rival early childcare company Mayfield Education, alarming experts who say providers that fail to meet baseline safety standards are being allowed to expand without oversight.

items.title: Given the all clear from cancer, 6yo Laylah celebrates by ringing the bell at the Queensland Children's Hospital

items.title: How domestic violence offenders use the court system to inflict more pain
items.summary: Jessica Seage fought for six years for the man who raped her to be convicted. Experts say her experience is a stark example of how perpetrators abuse the system to inflict more pain on their victims.

items.title: Long-awaited wine industry mandatory code of conduct too late for growers
items.summary: After 20 years, three senate inquiries and an independent review, the sale of wine grapes will be regulated by a mandatory code of conduct, but growers say it might be too late.

items.summary: If successful, it would be the third oil tanker seized as Donald Trump continues his campaign on President Nicolas Maduro.

items.title: England's Bazballers finally admit they've got things wrong in this Ashes series
items.summary: Losing an Ashes Test series in Australia is nothing new for England, but finally the Bazballers are looking inwards at their own failings after a stirring end to the Adelaide Test.

items.title: Insolvent business run by former AFL star wipes its debt of millions, and the taxpayer is left to foot the bill
items.summary: A digital marketing agency run by a former AFL star has wiped its millions in debt through an insolvency process, only to open under a new ABN days later. Former staff were left without a job and almost $450,000 in unpaid entitlements, but it's within the bounds of the law and leaves taxpayers footing the bill.

items.summary: What makes the AI-driven stock market bubble unique in history is that if it's not a bubble, the impact on humanity could be far more challenging than any previous technology.

items.summary: Thousands of people heard messages of defiance and resilience, along with calls for “light, love and unity”, as they gathered at Bondi Beach to mark one week since the devastating terrorist attack. Look back on how events unfolded.

items.summary: Most Australians live by the beach, but the coastline we have built our lives around is disappearing before our eyes.

items.title: The Hidden Line: Art of the Boyd Women uncovers the stories of the women in Arthur Boyd's family
items.summary: A new exhibition highlights the women behind acclaimed Australian mid-century artist Arthur Boyd, bringing their overlooked stories and art practices to the fore.

items.title: White and grey kangaroos to be sold to prevent overcrowding at Bordertown Wildlife Park
items.summary: White western grey kangaroos are a popular sight in a small wildlife park nestled near the South Australia – Victoria border and some are now being sold.

items.title: How 3D movie animation technology is helping injured athletes
items.summary: The reasons for high rates of serious knee injuries among female athletes are not fully understood.

items.title: Who's named in the Jeffrey Epstein files and who else was he connected to?
items.summary: The Epstein files offer another glimpse into the financier's vast network of wealthy and influential figures. Here's what we know about his relationships with some of the world's most powerful people.

items.title: Spain uses an algorithm to rank how safe women are. Sometimes it's wrong
items.summary: In Spain, police have developed technology to work out how at-risk women might be from domestic violence. Some people have grave concerns about how often the algorithm is wrong.

items.title: Christmas movies quiz: How well do you know festive films?
items.summary: From Home Alone to Nightmare Before Christmas, how well do you know these Christmas classics?

items.title: How Psy's billion-views trailblazer Gangnam Style presaged K-pop dominance
items.summary: Who'd have guessed a South Korean man doing a goofy horse dance was a recipe for a global phenomenon? Thirteen years after it made YouTube history we revisit the legacy of Psy's Gangnam Style.

items.title: With heads bowed after the Bondi terror attack, now is the time to listen to the Jewish community
items.summary: If we are to inch towards unity, the more we pause to listen, the more sure-footed our path forward will be.

items.title: Former Pakistani PM Imran Khan and wife Bushra Bibi given 17-year jail sentence in new graft case
items.summary: The case against Imran Khan and his wife Bushra Bibi centres on the alleged misuse of luxury state gifts from Saudi Arabia.

items.title: England abandons Bazball but is still no match for Australia with Ashes triumph imminent
items.summary: England's belated abandonment of Bazball gives it temporary life, but reveals a painful truth — no version of this team is a match for the soon-to-be victorious Australians.

items.title: Marnus Labuschagne takes miracle catch and Nathan Lyon breaks England's resistance — quick hits from day four of third Ashes Test
items.summary: Australia finishes day four needing four wickets to reclaim the Ashes thanks to Marnus Labuschagne and Nathan Lyon. Here are the quick hits from day four of the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.title: Focus on Bill Clinton in Epstein Files raises questions about how curated the documents were
items.summary: The thousands of photos paint a picture of a life spent with the rich and famous but little that is incriminating to anyone but Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: Easy last-minute baked gifts
items.summary: From super-quick shortbread to giant chocolatey cookies, your guests will be delighted to take home something they will actually use.

items.title: Vanuatu continues to rebuild one year after devastating earthquake
items.summary: Tourists are returning to Vanuatu a year on from a major catastrophe. But many demolished buildings are yet to be rebuilt and some locals are frustrated with the pace of repairs.

items.title: In pictures: Surf lifesavers pay tribute to Bondi victims
items.summary: Hundreds of surf lifesavers and lifeguards, many of whom responded to the Bondi terror attack, form a human chain in a moving tribute to the 15 people killed.

items.title: A first look through the Epstein files reveals celebrity snaps, police notes and a lot of Bill Clinton
items.summary: The US Department of Justice today released thousands of files it holds on late sex offender and disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein. Here's what's been uncovered in just a few hours.

items.title: Rare pink platypus spotted in East Gippsland river

items.title: Rare pink platypus spotted in East Gippsland river by Melbourne fisherman
items.summary: In a remote river in Victoria's east, a fisherman says he has encountered an ultra-rare pink platypus, one of only a handful ever sighted in the past 200 years.

items.title: Why new Perth Glory coach Adam Griffiths might be Australian football's most interesting character
items.summary: In a team struggling to retain fans, in a league battling for attention, newly appointed Perth Glory coach Adam Griffiths may just be the man with the answers for both problems.

items.title: Kalgoorlie the glittering prize for Frenchman Bruno Vincent
items.summary: Bruno Vincent has spent his life searching for gold, so there was only one Australian city on his travel bucket list.

items.title: Ambitious plan to share Carnarvon's food bowl both locally and statewide faces hurdles
items.summary: Carnarvon's fresh produce could help Western Australia's food insecurity crisis, but there is concern not enough is being done to address the issue locally first.

items.title: Tasmanian government faces questions over Pulse advertising spend after it asked for an election
items.summary: The Tasmanian premier's department authorised more than $13,000 of taxpayer money to be spent with a local media organisation to promote the budget after the government asked for an election to be held, documents show.

items.title: How a Queensland family is pushing for change after a devastating loss
items.summary: Tyler Pask devoted his life to being an incredible father, selfless brother and a diligent emergency service worker for the Queensland Fire Department. Now his family is transforming their grief into encouraging other young men to access support for their mental health.

items.title: Paramatta Light Rail usage tipped to double next year despite numbers falling short in its first year
items.summary: While rider numbers fell short of expectations in 2025, next year the number of trips taken on the Parramatta Light Rail is expected to double.

items.title: US strikes dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria, officials say
items.summary: Described as "a declaration of vengeance" by US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, the strikes come after Donald Trump vowed retaliation for an attack on US personnel.

items.title: Grace Lillian Lee weaves a path from the Torres Strait to Paris
items.summary: Lee's woven, wearable art creations have catapulted her from Cairns and the Torres Strait to Paris, a bustling textile mecca more than 15,000 kilometres away.

items.title: Islamic State made headlines after being linked to the Bondi attack. Here's why

items.summary: Hundreds of surf lifesavers have gathered on Bondi Beach to pay tribute to the victims of last Sunday's terrorist attack. Follow live.

items.title: Health and safety case against Tasmania's Adams gin distillery dismissed in court
items.summary: A work health and safety case against a distillery in Perth, northern Tasmania, is dismissed.

items.title: Dreams shattered as 140 Zone RV caravan customers' worst fears realised
items.summary: About 140 customers of Zone RV have been told they will not be receiving their caravans after the company collapsed.

items.title: Epstein files partially released by US Department of Justice
items.summary: The Trump administration publishes the first tranche of the Epstein files, but the release of hundreds of thousands of documents looks to have been delayed.

items.title: Former patients 'left waiting for justice' after damning report into Brisbane's Wolston Park Mental Hospital
items.summary: Brisbane's Wolston Park Mental Hospital closed in 2001, but a 12-month review has shed light on its history of sexual abuse and patient mistreatment.

items.summary: Rising expenses across the festive season have driven a family of five in Brisbane to set a rule to only purchase Christmas presents from second-hand stores — and they've been pleasantly surprised by the treasures they've uncovered.

items.title: Murgon residents 'at breaking point' during end-of-year crime spike
items.summary: The crime rate spikes every year around the holidays, according to the police. Tensions are rising in the Murgon community, as residents say they don't feel safe in their homes.

items.title: Melbourne University Women's Football Club was once a powerhouse. Now it's at risk of folding
items.summary: Melbourne University is the latest women’s Aussie Rules club fighting for survival, but it is hoping intervention from an AFL executive can turn the club’s fortunes around.

items.title: Oxford evolutionary researcher says humans may have been kissing Neanderthals
items.summary: Why is swapping saliva something all human societies have normalised? Turns out kissing isn't just a human thing — all sorts of species appear to kiss, and new research suggests Neanderthals did it too.

items.title: Environmental experts, detection dogs team up to protect native freshwater turtles
items.summary: A team of environmental experts, Indigenous rangers and conservation detection dogs is working on recovering the population of native freshwater turtles.

items.title: Coronial inquest into deaths of cultural leaders Big Brother and Little Brother recommends spit hood ban
items.summary: The NT coroner makes nine recommendations following an inquest into the deaths of two disabled Aboriginal brothers who spent a number of years homeless in Alice Springs.

items.title: Grace Tame demands law reform after Diocese of Ballarat cleared of vicarious liability
items.summary: In every Australian state and the NT, churches cannot be held vicariously liable for historical child sexual abuse perpetrated by their priests. Grace Tame is leading the charge for change.

items.title: BOM Christmas weather forecast shows cool day in the east, searing heat in the west
items.summary: Australia is experiencing a smorgasbord of wild weather in the lead-up to Christmas, featuring extreme heat, humidity, severe thunderstorms, and tropical storms all on the cards.

items.title: The teacher, driver and host who helped strangers take refuge during the Bondi terror attack

items.title: Today in history: Picasso painting worth millions stolen in daring art heist
items.summary: The 2007 Brazilian heist was not the last time a nimble thief made off with a Picasso. And as many Melburnians know, it certainly wasn't the first.

items.title: US to miss deadline to release all Epstein files, Trump official admits
items.summary: Deputy Attorney-General Todd Blanche says several hundred thousand Epstein-related documents should be released by the legal deadline, but several hundred thousand more could be a "couple of weeks" away.

items.title: Anthony Albanese faces primary test of his prime ministership in Bondi response
items.summary: While the prime minister will forever struggle to shed the perception that he was too slow to recognise the threat to Australia's Jewish community, he is taking action.

items.title: Famine ends in Gaza, Integrated Food Security Phase Classification report says
items.summary: A report by the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification is still warning that over 100,000 children face malnutrition over the coming months.

items.title: Smashed windscreen in remote SA unlikely caused by meteorite, museum says
items.summary: Scientists were hoping an object that smashed the windscreen of a self-driving car in October was a meteorite, but SA Museum's investigation says it remains a mystery.

items.title: Search suspended for deep-sea diver Timothy Bennett in Coral Sea
items.summary: A professional deep-sea diver, with several fish species named in his honour, is remembered as a loving father and well-respected in the science community for his contributions to the study of fish species.

items.title: Teens sentenced over deadly Wollongong street brawl fuelled by social media group chat
items.summary: A social media feud between teenage girls in Wollongong in 2023 erupted into a deadly street fight, leaving Kristie McBride dead and several teens now sentenced for her manslaughter.

items.title: Marlinyu Ghoorlie native title group in Goldfields celebrates recognition as traditional owners

items.title: Mayday called after CFA fire trucks broke down during emergency level blaze near Benalla
items.summary: A Country Fire Authority crew was forced to call for help after their tanker broke down while fighting an emergency level blaze near Benalla.

items.title: Travis Head, the last of Australia's larrikins, revels in his Ashes summer of love
items.summary: Travis Head has become Australia's most beloved cricketer, and as another glorious Ashes century guided his team ever closer to the urn, he was eager to return the love.

items.title: Chris Scott re-signs as Geelong coach until the end of the 2029 AFL season
items.summary: Already the longest serving coach in Geelong history, Chris Scott's new deal with the club will put him in the company of some of the AFL's greatest ever mentors.

items.title: Bedford creditors vote to hand over reins to The Disability Trust
items.summary: Creditors have voted to support the sale of Bedford to NDIS provider The Disability Trust, which would guarantee the jobs of 1,100 workers.

items.title: Communities rally to battle tragic fires near Ongerup and support each other in wake of tragedy
items.summary: Following fatal fires in Western Australia's south earlier this week, stories are emerging of how homes were saved and communities rallied in the wake of tragedy.

items.title: Gun law debate raises questions about why some own scores of firearms
items.summary: In the wake of the Bondi terror attack and upcoming government firearms restrictions, some people are asking why anyone would need to own 100 guns.

items.title: Family demands probe into NSW Police use of force after video of Dubbo arrest
items.summary: An Aboriginal man who was known by NSW Police to have mental health issues was hospitalised after his arrest over a traffic stop.

items.title: EU leaders agree on $160b loan to Ukraine after plan to use frozen Russian assets unravels
items.summary: EU leaders agree to provide a massive interest-free loan to Ukraine to meet its military and economic needs for the next two years after failing to reach an agreement on the use of frozen Russian assets.

items.title: Sydney man Danny Zayat jailed for 24 years over DV murder of ex-partner Tatiana Dokhotaru
items.summary: The stepfather of Tatiana Dokhotaru, killed by her ex-partner Danny Zayat, tells a court of her remarkable courage as Zayat is jailed for 24 years.

items.title: Tasmania's proposed short-stay levy 'unjust', tourism industry argues
items.summary: The tourism industry remains opposed to a 5 per cent levy on short-stay accommodation that the Tasmanian government has promised to implement.

items.title: Dayna Isaac's murderer Paul Sultana sentenced to 44 years in prison
items.summary: A judge labelled intimate partner violence "a scourge in a civilised society" when he sentenced Paul Sultana to 44 years in jail for the murder of Dayna Isaac.

items.title: Dimboola woman who told undercover police she gouged elderly man's eyes found not guilty of murder
items.summary: Jodie Hill wept as a Supreme Court jury found her not guilty of murder and manslaughter, follow a week of deliberations.
